item.title: Manifesto
item.description:
“The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race.”

The quadratic formula is:

int main(){
 cout<<test"al";
}
$$ E = mc^2 $$
import os
print("Anarchy rules")
\[ \begin{aligned} KL(\hat{y} || y) &= \sum_{c=1}^{M}\hat{y}_c \log{\frac{\hat{y}_c}{y_c}} \\ JS(\hat{y} || y) &= \frac{1}{2}(KL(y||\frac{y+\hat{y}}{2}) + KL(\hat{y}||\frac{y+\hat{y}}{2})) \end{aligned} \]

Everyone should have a website where they can show their inner anarchy free of censorship and run it on-prem.

item.title: Visual Based Game Cheats
item.description:
I made this project as part of Syntax Error organized by SDSLabs.

This project is probably the one I’m most proud of. It’s not the most complex one, but I created it all in one day from scratch, and everything worked. The only bummer is that the judges couldn’t run it (wasn’t a one click go).

item.title: Prey-Predator Simulation
item.description:
I made this project as part of WOC organized by SDSLabs.

It is a Python-based simulation where you can tweak the initial conditions and other parameters of an environment and then prey-predator adapt to each other and try to survive for a long time. (You are not playing GOD!)

item.title: Snake Playing Algorithm
item.description:
I made this project a while back after getting inspiration from a video from AlphaPhoenix.

(Everything above this line is the summary. Everything below is the “Hidden” detail).

The path-finding algorithm is not that complex; to be honest, the snake always follows a Hamiltonian path, and whenever it can cut the board in such a way that it can return to the original Hamiltonian path, it will cut the board and save some moves.
